results.title: Changes, changes (K)
results.creator_credit: Gene Deitch, Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: Set to the music of an all-wood orchestra, this simple un narrated story portrays a pair of wooden dolls which magically come to life. Initially the blocks formed a house for the man and lady. They then change into a fire engine to put out a fire in the house and into a truck, train and ship to take the wooden couple on a holiday. Finally they form a house again. Adapted from the book of the same title by Pat Hutchins. Animation by Zdenka Skripkova. Suitable for lower and middle primary levels.

results.title: Chamberlain vs Hitler
results.creator_credit: Alan Landsburg, David L. Wolper and Wolper Productions

results.title: Challenge of progress
results.creator_credit: Sean Graham and Gold Coast Film Unit
results.brief_description: Today the Gold Coast (Africa) is no longer a backward country. New roads and buildings are being constructed, people are learning new skills and trades and the country is making rapid political progress. However, democracy canot be superimposed from above. The people of the country must be educated to accept new responsibilities. This film shows how new schools, technical colleges and training centres are being built to bring formal education to the young people of the Gold Coast. At the adult level, mass education projects are under way, through which the adults of the community are learning to read and write, and, more important, are learning how to raise their standard of living.

results.title: Century of progress
results.creator_credit: V.R. Sarma, M. Bhavnani and Documentary Films of India
results.brief_description: A survey of the Indian Railways, the story of the fulfilment of a 100-year-old dream. April 16, 1953, marked the first centenary of the Indian Railways. In 1853 the first rails were laid between Bombay and Thana. Where once only the hoof-beat of the bullock or pony could be heard, the iron horse now thunders. India now possesses the largest railway system in Asia and the third largest in the world. Commentary by Berkeley Hill.
results.creator_credit_for_label: V.R. Sarma, M. Bhavnani and Documentary Films of India

results.title: Centripetal force and satellite orbits
results.brief_description: Demonstrates how mass, velocity and radius affect the magnitude of centripetal force. States this effect in equation form and solves a problem involving the velocity needed to hold a satellite in orbit. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Celtic tides
results.creator_credit: Mark Hall, Gregory Hall, Cottonport Holdings and Nashmount Productions
results.brief_description: Featuring footage from seventeen recorded tracks as a backdrop, ‘Celtic tides’ takes the viewer on a cultural journey through the origins of celtic music, including interviews with performers, fans and Celtic historians who all share a passion for this vibrant music scene and display a thorough knowledge of the music’s evolution. Individual songs and performers on the tape include: Drunken piper” (Natalie MacMaster and Cookie Rankin), “An Innis aigh (The Chieftans, The Rankin Family), “Theme from Harry’s game” (Clannad), “Ta me mo shui” (Altan), “Flesh & blood” (Mary Black), “O’Neill’s march” (The Chieftans), “Step dance” (The Rankin Family), “Jack Daniels” (Natalie MacMaster), “Brenda Stubbert” (Ashley MacIsaac), “Boxty set” (Altan), “Traditional” (Old Blind Dogs), “A Cur nan goghar as a chreig” (Capercaillie), “Sleepy Maggie” (Ashley MacIsaac), “Caledonia” (Dougie MacLean), “Lady of Shalott” (Loreena McKennitt), “Seamus piping” (Seamus Egan), “E Horo” (Mary Jane Lamond). Hosted by the Rankin family.

results.title: Cellluloid
results.brief_description: Celluloid was the first material used in the mass production of motion picture film. Made from highly flammable Cellulose Nitrate and prone to combustion when running through a projector, Celluloid was replaced in the 1950s by Acetate otherwise known as Safety Film.
results.description: Celluloid was the first material used in the mass production of motion picture film. Made from highly flammable Cellulose Nitrate and prone to combustion when running through a projector, Celluloid was replaced in the 1950s by Acetate otherwise known as Safety Film.

results.title: Cell division in closterium
results.brief_description: Uses electron microscopy, polarisation optics and other techniques to show cell division in the closterium. Each stage in the process is described and explained.

results.title: Cell differentiation: the search for the organiser (TEFC)
results.brief_description: When do permanent differences appear among an embryo’s cells? Using experiments with embryo salamanders, scientists follow the development of cell growth and differentiation. Embryologist, Hans Spemann, discovers the organiser, that group of cells which differentiates first then induces differentiation of other cells around it. This work laid the basis for modern developmental biology.
